title: Pension plan makes GM look less enticing
text:
July 31, 2015 12:16 am Pension plan makes GM look less enticing The Nikkei has no letters column, so I write to you 
Sir, The implied valuation of GM (“ General Motors : on the Buffett table”, Lex, July 29) would certainly be enticing if true. Not taken account of in the analysis are several factors, including the company’s vast pension underfunding, which, while listed at $24.1bn at fiscal year-end, is actually closer to $29.4bn when more realistic actuarial assumptions are utilised. Additionally, the failure of GM to fund the plan properly leads investors into believing their cash flows and GAAP results are higher than economic reality would dictate. For instance, for its last fiscal year, GM contributed just $913m versus almost $7.5bn in benefit payments. Such underfunding has taken place each year post the IPO. 
The upcoming end of federal pension — MAP 21 — relief will only add to the burden. In addition, GM’s periodic pension cost, the amount shown on the profit and loss, of just $151m is puny in relation to the true liability and yearly benefit obligations, while inflating both GAAP income and commonly defined cash flows. 
Finally, GM’s financial subsidiaries will require greater amounts of cash if the company is to grow. During its latest fiscal year, GM Financial saw its accounts receivables grow by almost 14 per cent, or $3.9bn. 
All in all, given these considerations, GM’s cash flow to enterprise value is closer to 8.4 times, rather than Lex’s 3 times. I would thus be quite surprised if Warren Buffett made a play for the entire enterprise.
